text: this is Neil MacFarquhar
in Ginny moly this ancient city is
famous for its mud mosque the largest
mud brick building in the world is a
major tourist attraction a giant sand
castle dominating the town's renowned
Market Square everything in Jena from
the post office to individual homes is
built with mud bricks the town is a
United Nations World Heritage Site this
is a generic it's a cylinder and it's
different from a normal brick but the
Heritage status has led to friction here
homeowners resent the fact that under UN
rules for heritage sites they cannot
modernize any remodeling even inside
their homes must stick to the original
design it pleases the population because
the town is well known but the owners of
the houses should be able to make small
changes to the interior of their houses
but the facades would stay the same all
the buildings and particularly the
mosque require constant upkeep as you
can see on the upper part of the mosque
courtyard walls the plaster has washed
away after just three or four rainstorms
all around the brick you can see the
marks of hands we do it all by hand
which means that every man who does it
leaves a part of himself in the brick
but the traditional restoration methods
take money the restoration of the Great
Mosque alone is a nine hundred thousand
dollar project funded by the ArchiCAD
foundation there is no such bounty for
homeowners and while they take pride in
the tradition of these homes they feel
like they are just pieces in a museum
designed to entertain tourists you don't
like there's a sort of tension
difficulty that has to be resolved by
not locking in people with the so-called
traditional and authentic architecture
now's in architectural tradition we have
to try to find ways to evolve this
architecture to bring it back to the
necessities of life for the community
the community and do it in such a way
that doesn't compromise the quality of
the mud brick architecture sepals
compliment back alley which is at the
heart of the identity of the town
actionability amendment in Virginia the
town has failed to modernize in other
essential ways jenny is drowning in
garbage open sewers run through the
streets and a rotting smell hangs over
the town add into the mix climate change
which has lowered the river waters and
lessen the quality of the mud which in
turn weakens the bricks and the
buildings the Malian government and
foreign organizations are now turning
their attention to Jenny's problems
trying to balance the frustration of the
residents with history if you destroy
the history the tourists come to visit
if you throw out 2,000 years of history
if you destroy all that the city will
lose its soul
you
